text: 11/15 Dark amber to light umber in color. Smallish ecru head. Aromas of caramel, light spices of nutmeg, cloves and cinnamon. A bit of alcohol and menthol with a big sniff. Lots of malt in the front. Simple caramel and light toasted flavors. Some light citrus and spices in the middle. Finish is lightly sweet with a touch of fruitiness and a slight ginger bite. A spiced Oktoberfest. Interesting.

Pours a clear copper-golden with a light khaki head. Pumpkin pie and fainter notes of caramel on the nose. Flavors are the same except for a peculiar bitter off flavor that persists through and beyond the finish.
12oz bottle from Rays in Tosa. Reddish orange pour. Sweet and tangy. Spicy malts. Some surprising pumpkin/allspice. Tasty. A blend of the two autumn styles. 13.3
Rich amber/cider color; Medium slightly creamy body; Aroma of malt, caramel/toffee, some cola, & spice; Flavor of sweet malt, nice caramel, some hops, and spice; Nicely balanced; Very decent,

Old note. Savor Growl, dont remember whether tap or bottle: ammber pour, finger light tan, dissapears quickly.aroma of yeasty, spices, cinnamon? tastes are milky, wheat, sweet and sour. strange. clove, spices? oily light to medium. faint spike of carbonation. not bad, but strange - 7.0

Poured from the bottle into a pint glass to drink. The beer had a mostly clear amber-orange color with a modest foamy off-white head with modest retention, cling, and lacing. Its aroma featured a strong presence of caramel, along with some herbal scents and spices, and a bit of straw and banana. The taste was mostly sweet and milky, with a strong presence of caramel, and some nice light spicing. It was a fairly wet and watery beer with below average carbonation and a lighter, thinner mouthfeel.

bottle @ Chief Market / Lima OH --- Clear dark amber color, off-white head that drops to a cover, bands of lace. Taste is caramel malt that light fizz and light spice on the swallow, moving on to a nearly hop-less finish in which the sweet abates enough a achieve a balance. Sweet, but good.

Bottle at Boundary. Pours a clear amber copper with a near white head that dissipates nearly completely. Aroma has dark grains and a bit of dark fruits and a touch of toffee. Flavor has a decent amount of spice with dark grains and some toffee underlying.

Draft at Elijah Ps. Pours a clear orange-hued gold with a finger of creamy off-white head that settles into a ring and film. The bartenders deScription of "like liquid flan" was apt; notes o ftoasted sugar, caramel, floral and fruity funk, faint spices (cinnamon and ginger, perhaps?), grass, and bread. Light-medium bodied, with moderate carbonation and a sweet, malty mouthfeel. Interesting beer, and an interesting take on the style. These guys are always good for mixing it up that way.

Taste: caramel milk sweetness with a dash of Fall spices, smooth and very drinkable.
Red Cooper hue, clear, with a delicate tan head.
malty dulce de leche, with a veggie note to nose.
Medium body.
Unique take on a Marzen.

Sample at the zombie themed beer tasting and Shaun of the Dead screening at Studio 35 on 10/11/15. Clear copper pour with a medium tan head. Aroma of cinnamon, caramel and malt. Malty and caramelly flavor with a spicy cinnamon finish.
Draught at Mas, Chicago. Malty and spicy Okterbest. Dark orange. Slightly different take.

Fresh bottle from one of the cousins in the barrio. Nose is not what I expected from the style. The caramel is not as pronounced as I thought it would be. Sip adds nutmeg or the sweet ingredient in Cherry NyQuil. More of a veg/herb/spice beer for me. Decent and perfect for October. Easy to drink and very flavorful. After a little research the Hoja Santa is also known as the root beer plant.

Links, Chicago tap: pours reddish with a small white head and no lacing. Aroma is condensed milk, all spice, and malt. Taste is kind of roundly sweet and plenty spicy. I guess you either like these flavors or you dont. i dont really. Meh.

Extra from flandersned-thanks, Steve! Murky brown. Nice enough nose of sweet cream, malts, light spice. Taste is creamy, sweet lactose, with loads of caramel, and some spice. Doesnt work for me but sure some love this.

Pours a clear caramel color that lacks a head. The aroma is heavy on cinnamon and spices, along with some nutmeg, toffee, and bread. The taste is dry. There is nutmeg and spices up front, moving into orange, ginger, and cinnamon. Hints of breadiness, minor yeast and apple as well. The aftertaste is a short spicy apple flavor. Medium bodied, more thin in texture, and having some softer carbonation. This one isnt all that bad. Im not sure Id purchase it again, but Id have no problem drinking one again.

Pour on tap, dark orange-red pour with white head, aroma brought notes of caramel, toffee, lots of yeasty and hoppy spice into a bit of grass, big spice notes from cinnamon, nutmeg and allspice come through as well. Taste is a mix of cinnamon, clove, some ginger into a bit of caramel, toffee, slight grass, touch of bread, finishing fairly sweet, slightly spicy.

Just not a great beer. I have not had a good one out of this brewery. They call it an octoberfest but it is a little spicy and smells like socks. Hard to choke down. Pours a nice cooper color 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

(bottle - 12 oz) Orange pour with a fizzy white head. Heavy spice aroma with a nice malt undertone. Flavor is a good Oktoberfest base but then a ton of spices and sweetness from the milk caramel. Sweet and really smooth.

Pours amber-orange with a minimal head. Aroma is yeasty and spicy (nutmeg/cinnamon kinda spicy). Taste is "wet" and spicy. Its like a pumpkin beer blended with an easy to drink Oktoberfest Märzen. There seems to be a hoppy presence in the mid. Definitely interesting and if you imagine the dulce de leche, you can pick it up. Curious as to why it is called "life and death"? P.S. - I guess I should read the brewers description. Duh.
Semisweet chocolate, dash of caramel, drinks kinda like a midway between a porter and a festbier, really tasty and awesome despite not being totally to style.

Clearish tea color. Tight khaki head. Bad tap label. Light lemony tea aroma with some florality. Soapy mouthfeel... a little on the light side with the body. Lightly candied effect, but not sweet. Very lightly tannic. Lightly acidic finish. On tap, Brass Tap,Tallahassee Midtown.

Tallahassee, Fl - New Leaf Market - 12 oz bottle. Pours a slightly sparkling medium copper with an initial bubbly off-white head that dissipates quickly. Aroma has some light caramel and dates. Flavor is decent and on the sweet side with some caramel notes, a touch of raisins, just a light hint of chocolate. Clean, even mouthfeel. Does in a pinch.

Bottle. Poured clear copper color with an average frothy off-white head that mostly lasted with good lacing. Moderate toasted sweet malt aroma. Medium body with a smooth texture and soft carbonation. Medium toasted sweet flavor with a medium sweet finish of moderate duration. My expectations where met.

12oz bottle, from Dutchs. Half hazy amber orange color, a bit darker. Thin off-white head, leaving a few bits of lace. Really interesting aroma for an oktoberfest, much more complex. Drinks like an ale.. Medium body. Super smooth, kind of crisp, lighter carbonation. Light slick. Super smooth and easy-drinking. Great flavor. Dulce le leche is a very creative thing to add to a Marzen, and it seems to add a ton of character here, that complements the natural caramel malt flavors of the style very nicely. Kind of a tropical fruity hop character. I dont know if its that fancy leaf contributing this, but theres also a nice touch of a kind of minty earthy herbal factor towards the finish... Awesome journey of flavor here. Moderate sweet taste, light to moderate bitter, lightly spicy. Very enjoyable, tasty, interesting stuff. Fruity hop seems to make this for me, as typically the style is too sweet... The taste here is much more balanced than your typical marzen, despite all the additions. I normally insist on pairing this style with food, but this beer was interesting and easy-drinking enough to hold up on its own easily. Much better than expected... Ive heard some people say that 5 Rabbits has gotten much better lately, and considering the last few things Ive had from them, I have to agree.

Sampled at Beer Hoptacular 5. A light peppery spiciness greets the nose with a touch of bread crust. It pours a clear, pale orange with a dense, medium white ring. A light dusting is left on the surface with a very light hint of lace. The taste is a light sweet and very light spce bitter. The beer is crisp, dry, and light with thin texture and an airy zip to the carbonation. It finishes with spice and bread, then cleans up quickly leaving only a touch of pepper on the aftertaste.
No arguments other than not as advertised. Very smooth, easy to drink.. not bitter at all. Oktoberfest?

Pint on tap at Bad Apple in Chicago. Pleasant cayenne pepper spice and grain in the aroma. Dark copper orange with lots of bubbles and an off white head. Taste is very smooth and hotter, spicier than most marzens. The malted sweetness and the pepper spice pair nicely, like a Central American candy. Palate is medium bodied, easy drinking. Overall, one of the more interesting and satisfying variations of an Oktoberfest I've had in some time.

Decent beer but not even close to a maerzen. Caramel and spices dominate all the way.Earlier Rating: 9/10/2013 Total Score: 2.8Spiced beer with a caramel apple flavor. Super hazy served on cask. Its okay.

On tap @ Jake Melnicks, Chicago. Tawny orange amber, clear, with a generous lasting white head. Very spicy aroma of nutmeg, ginger, with underlying sweet caramel. Cakey spicy flavour profile, clean finish. Yum!
user_location: the land of bitumen, beef & beer, Alberta, CANADA

text: On tap at Fatpour Chicago. Sweet slightly boozy aroma. Flavor is sweet and caramelly with some rich spice notes. Tastes like a darker Tripel as it doesnt have the hop bite of a typical Oktoberfest and is much sweeter. I really liked it but I understand why some would say its a little flat.

Poured from a bottle.  Brownish. Lots of sticky head. Not much aroma. Fruity backbone on a malty earthy beer.  Pretty tasty

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Enjoyed on tap at Reggies in Chicago, IL prior to seeing the band Tragedy.  I didnt take tasting notes for this one but I remember it being pretty good.  Appearance a murky dark brown with not much head at all.  Aroma was sweet, definite caramel presence.  Taste was pretty good, definitely a good mixture of Belgian candi, sweetness, clove, and cinnamon.  Moderate body and carbonation.  Of the 5 Rabbit stuff Ive tried so far this was hands down the best of their brews.
On tap at Sheffields, amber pour, Carmel and spice with a creamy mouth feel, dulce de lychee finish.

On tap @ Fountainhead. Finally tried this one, gotta support the locals. Pours a deep amber with moderate beige head, mostly diminishing. Good lacing. Caramel and a bit of spice notes such as nutmeg, brown sugar and piloncillo on the nose. Very good going down - well balanced and finishes just right. Tasted some notes of Dulce de leche at the finish. Smooth and easy drinking. Glad I tried it.

On tap at the Bavarian Lodge in Lisle, IL., and dispensed to a pint glass with a bright and clear, deep copper color, a modest amount of off white head foam that diminished rather quickly to a ring & film, and left some dots & dashes of lacing. The nose was sweetness, caramel, vanilla, a hint of banana, and pie spice less clove. The flavor started with a low but mildly lingering hop bitterness that was peppery & earthy, and then continued the aroma notes. The body was medium+, there was a light silkiness to the mouthfeel, and the texture was a little sticky. Flavorful, nice complexity, but considering the style line, a little sweet for me.

Draft at Long Room Chicago. Pours a deep copper color with a small off white head. Aroma is sweet, a bit candy like, lots of caramel, toffee a light spice to it. Flavor is caramel sweet with a definitely bit of milky quality, just a hint of roast and a light grainy sweet finish. Medium body and a soft carbonation. Decent, not one of my favorites from them though
my 4th, and favorite, rabbit so far. nutmeg or cinnamon, im not sure. dulce y rica.

Draft at Map Room (Chicago, IL). A treat to try a new 5 Rabbit brew. Pours a glowing lively copper hue, no real haze as the fiery appearance takes gold, frothy offwhite head sits atop and dies to a film, laces small overall. Aromas are spicy, nutmeg and faint cinnamon mix with some sweetness, caramel and toffee with some touches of dulce de leche sweetness, a bit odd, touch of toastiness and dryness from some gentle hops. Initial is medium bodied, perhaps a touch lighter, offering sweet caramel and milk sugars, a touch of toast, toffee, and gentle earthy hops, spice, mellow cinnamon and nutmeg. A very unique brew, into the finish drying up a bit more with the help of earthy hops and gentle spice that lingers on. Certainly an interesting beer. In spite of that, the elements work and stay fairly balanced despite what you would expect to not work at all. Look forward to more from the 5 Rabbit crew.

5 Rabbit Vida y Muerte Muertzenbier
On tap at the Map Room for their 19th anniversary. Pours a hazed, copper-gold colored body with a finger-width, dense and foamy, off-white head that dissipates slowly and leaves a nice lacing throughout. Aroma is lightly toasted caramel with some grain and a light bread along with a nice, light spicing that balances well. Resembles pumpkin pie spices with some cinnamon and nutmeg. The caramel gives off a nice, light richness as well. Flavor is similar. Richer caramel with a light spicing up front. Some grains and a light earthy hopping come out in the middle as well as a bit of fruitiness. Caramel stays balanced, but gets a bit richer in the finish as the spicing increases slightly and helps this finish fairly dry, but balanced with a light sweetness. Lengthy aftertaste following a medium, smooth body and a moderate carbonation. Overall, all the 5 Rabbit beers Ive tried have all been really well balanced and fairly subtle. This is no different. Very well put together with a light, but rich caramel along with a nice earthy spicing. This wasnt the most complex or bold beer around, but I enjoyed it.
draft... really clear lightest possible copper, watery off white head... the aroma is terrible, nutmeg with feet, horrendous... the taste is equally as bad, this not good at all, pass

Draft at Bad Apple. Pours a bright copper, frothy head. Nose is curious. Lots of light spice, nutmeg, cinnamon and dulce de leche. Spicy and herbal hops. come across the nose as well. Definitely out of place as a marzen, but not objectionable overall. On taste, this is the most aggressive of the 5 Rabbit beers yet. Strong notes of milk caramel and light vanilla. Some faint cinnamon as well. Quite. Lean and refreshing with a nice sweetness. Definitely unique. Solid.
